awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Wavenumber Spiral Frequency-Steerable Acoustic Transducer for Structural Health Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is related to reductions in inspection and maintenance costs of commercial and military aircraft. As the average age of existing aircraft is extending beyond the design life, fatigue cracks are a major issue that requires close monitoring to ensure continued airworthiness. Extensive and time consuming manual non-destructive inspection programs have been implemented to monitor and insure the safety and structural integrity of the aircraft. The Wavenumber Spiral Frequency-Steerable Acoustic Transducer (WS-FSAT) is a Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) sensor that enables inspection of in hard-to-reach areas within an aircraft or other asset, where significant structural risk is present, and promises to enable remote inspection of critical structures without disassembly. The technology has the advantage of inherent directional sensing capabilities over relatively wide areas, which translates to lower size, weight and installation costs. Potential benefits include the reduction of the time and cost of inspections, and of the associated aircraft downtime, and of structural integrity risks through more frequent monitoring of structural risk areas. The proposed I-Corp program explores implementation and commercialization opportunities of the technology within the aerospace industry and its broader applicability for inspection and monitoring of structural components.

This I-Corps project explores application and market opportunities for the Wavenumber Spiral Frequency-Steerable Acoustic Transducer (WS-FSAT). The WS-FSAT is a novel ultrasonic transducer that enables in-situ, nondestructive inspection of aircraft structures to detect defects that impact structural integrity and safety. WS-FSATs have inherent directional capabilities with the ability to detect, locate and characterize structural defects with significantly lower hardware and signal processing complexity than other approaches. The WS-FSAT maps the direction of wave sensing to a specific frequency component in the spectrum of the received signal, which greatly facilitates the identification and localization of damage. These directional capabilities rely on the design of the electrodes on a sensing substrate that performs the transduction of mechanical strains associated with waves propagating in the structure to an electrical signal. Such design process is at the core of the technology, and is suitable to meet the needs of inspection of complex structural components.

por.por_cntn:
The WS-FSAT is a novel guided wave transducer that enables in-situ, nondestructive inspection of structural components to detect cracks, corrosion and other defects that impact structural integrity and safety. WS-FSATs have inherent directional capabilities with the ability to detect, locate and characterize structural defects with significantly lower hardware and signal processing complexity than other approaches. The WS-FSAT maps the direction of wave sensing in the to a specific frequency component in the spectrum of the received signal. The WS-FSAT operating in sensing mode can be also employed for localization of impact events, whereby source location is identified through the time-frequency analysis of the received signal. The frequency selective response of the WS-FSAT directly maps the dominant component of the received signal to the direction of arrival of the incoming wave, thus greatly facilitating the source localization procedure. The directional capabilities of the WS-FSAT rely on the design of the electrodes on a piezoelectric substrate, that performs the transduction of mechanical strains associated with waves propagating in the structure to an electrical signal. Such design process is at the core of the technology, and is suitable to meet the needs of inspection of complex structural components.The WS-FSAT technology provides an enabling tool to lower the cost of structural inspections without compromising safety.. The technology also contributes to the industry trend toward condition based maintenance (CBM), that is, maintenance based on actual condition, rather than currently used scheduled maintenance. Critical to CBM is the ability to monitor structural health. CBM promises to offer lower cost and higher efficiencies to operators. WS-FSAT is one of the technologies that will allow CBM to become reality. Moreover, the WS-FSAT could prove beneficial for the inspection of a variety of other structural components in civil infrastructure and in the automotive and railway transportation fields, among others. 

Initially, the target market for this technology was considered the commercial and military aircraft aftermarket due to the high value needs and the ability of this technology to uniquely satisfy needs of large aging fleets. However, through the NSF I-Corps program, the team has conducted an in-depth customer discovery, which has found a significantly more promising market for quick transition and potential growth. Based on the findings of over one hundred customer discovery interviews completed in March, April and May 2017, and subsequently throughout the duration of the project, the team has identified the petrochemical industry as a very suitable and promising area of application. There is a broad need to manage the risk of petrochemical storage, piping and vessel structural integrity in order to prevent leaks or failures which would release liquid or gas into the environment. Therefore, the team will focus on this field by investigating research needs and open issues that will enable the demonstration of this technology for the specific applications.

Indeed, the team has discovered that there exist significant regulatory hurdles to overcome before an income can be generated from the commercialization of the WS-FSAT technology. Thus, based on our in-depth customer discovery activity, we have made contacts with several petrol-chemical companies and decided to switch our attention to research needs and opportunities in this field. The market for this innovation is the non-destructive inspection market. This market for NDT equipment was approximately $2.5 billion in 2016, or 39% of the total $6.51 billion market for NDT services and equipment market. We are targeting the Power Generation and Oil & Gas industry, which represents approximately 45% of the market at $1.18 billion. Aging infrastructure and assets in developed countries is increasing the need for maintenance and inspection. The increasing incidences of failures and leakages, increased safety regulations from Governments, as well as the escalating costs of failures are driving the demand for NDT solutions. The Oil & Gas industry is attempting to move to risk based inspection methodology, in order to use their resources more efficiently and save costs. However, this approach requires more information on the condition of their assets, which is driving the expanding adoption of new NDT technology. Moreover, there is a shortage of qualified NDT technicians, especially for advanced NDT technology which require a higher level of training. The lack of qualified technicians is a drag on the growth of the NDT market.
